newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Mandela kicks off first S.E. Asian tour in Manila.
newsitem.headline: Mandela kicks off first S.E. Asian tour in Manila.

text.p: South African President Nelson Mandela, accompanied for the first time on a state visit by his Mozambican sweetheart, arrived in Manila on Saturday at the start of his maiden tour of southeast Asia.

"This part of the world has made fantastic achievments economically and politically," Mandela told reporters. "I have looked forward to coming to this region because of the enormous lessons which we can learn in trying to raise the living conditions of our people."

Mandela and Graca Machel, the 51-year-old widow of former Mozambican president Somora Machel, were greeted by a 21-gun salute and a welcome with full military honours at the presidential palace in Manila.
Philippine president Fidel Ramos hailed Mandela as "one of the towering figures of the century".
"His struggle changed the face of race relations across the world," Ramos told a news conference.
"Visiting the Republic of the Philippines is the fulfillment of a long and cherished dream, an unforgettable experience," Mandela wrote in the visitors book at the palace.
Mandela introduced Graca, dressed in maroon and gold, as his "companion" to Ramos, who smiled and shook hands with her.

Asked by a reporter later if a wedding was in the offing, the 78-year-old Mandela said: "My cultural background does not permit me to discuss this question with people young enough to be my children or grandchildren".
Ramos, standing next to him, laughed and clapped, and Mandela would not speak more on the subject.

Mandela was divorced from his second wife Winnie last year after a bitter court battle in which he acknowledged she had been unfaithful to him. His first wife Evelyn lives in the rural south coast Transkei, where he has built a retirement home.
Both Mandela and Graca have previously said they have no plans to marry.
South African and Philippine officials also signed an agreement to expand cooperation in trade and investment and to grant each other "Most Favoured Nation" status in trade relations.
Ramos said investment links between the two countries could include projects in the energy, mining and railway sectors but details still had to be worked out.

Mandela was to meet former president Corazon Aquino later on Saturday and attend a state banquet. On Sunday, he will address members of the Makati Business Club, the country's premier group of businessmen.
He leaves for Brunei on Monday and will visit Malaysia and Singapore before returning to South Africa.
